The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" authorizes funds for the modernization of the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System. The Forest Service will study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a year. Increased criminal penalties for arsonists are also included in the Act. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" includes amendments to federal law regarding malicious use of fire or explosives, with increased penalties based on the extent of damage caused or risk to human life. Offenders could face fines, imprisonment, or both, depending on the circumstances listed in the subsection. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" imposes harsh penalties for offenders based on the extent of damage or harm caused. Offenders could face fines and imprisonment ranging from 8 to 40 years, with the possibility of the death penalty in cases of fatalities. Juvenile delinquents must spend time in a residential institution and perform 100-1000 hours of community service. The Forest Service will study federal legal impediments to clearing fire hazards and report to Congress within a year. The Secretary of Defense will report on utilizing military resources for firefighting. Firefighting water supply and backup power will be insured. SEC. 7. INSURING FIRE FIGHTING WATER SUPPLY AND BACKUP POWER.

The Forest Service, in consultation with local fire chiefs and experts, will study building additional roads and backup power supplies to ensure water availability in national forest areas for better fire fighting effectiveness. Results will be reported to Congress within a year.

SEC. 8. REVENUE OFFSET.

The Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost direct loans of the Farmers Home Administration by 5% for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
